conclusion: Consider forces acting on the metal rod and power dissipated in the rod.
The metal rod has a resistance of R and moves from position ab to a'b' with speed v1.
The rod is moving horizontally, so the only external force is the magnetic force due to the magnetic field.
Magnetic force F on the rod is given by F = BIL, where B is magnetic field strength, I is current in the loop, and L is length of the loop.
Magnetic force is perpendicular to the velocity of the rod and is constant, acting in the direction of motion.
Power P dissipated in the rod is given by P = I^2R, where I is current in the loop.
Since the rod is moving at a constant speed, the power dissipated in the rod is constant.
Current I in the loop is given by I = v/L, where v is velocity of the rod and L is length of the loop.
Since the rod is moving at a constant speed, the current in the loop is constant.
Ratio of the currents in the two processes is I1/I2 = v1/v2 = 1/2.
Power dissipated in the rod is constant, regardless of the speed of the rod.
Ratio of the powers of the external forces is P1/P2 = I1^2R/I2^2R = (I1/I2)^2 = (1/2)^2 = 1/4.
Final answer: Ratio of loop currents is 1/2 and ratio of powers of external forces is 1/4.
